text:section.text:h: Centre for Military Airworthiness and Certification (CEMILAC) Defence Research & Development Organisation (DRDO) Ministry of Defence, Government of India Marathahalli Colony Post, Bengaluru-560037

office:text.text:p: This report provides a comprehensive technical exposition of a production-ready Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) framework that integrates Redis and RediSearch for dual-mode retrieval using both HNSW vector similarity and BM25 lexical search. The system is designed to create a high-precision, fully auditable, and GPU-accelerated document question-answering pipeline suitable for offline or enterprise environments.

text:p.text:span: At its foundation, the architecture employs
for dense embeddings of text chunks, an optional

for combining multiple retrieval signals into a single robust ranking. The ingestion pipeline automates the processing of complex PDF documents through PyMuPDF for native text extraction and Tesseract for OCR fallback, ensuring resilience against scanned or image-based pages. It then performs sophisticated cleaning procedure

correcting ligatures, resolving line-break hyphenation, stripping headers, footers, and page numbers, and normalizing whitespace before chunking the text into overlapping sections that preserve semantic continuity. Each chunk is embedded on either GPU or CPU and stored in Redis as a HASH with both metadata and vector data, enabling simultaneous lexical and semantic retrieval through RediSearchs HNSW indexing and BM25 scoring. During inference, queries undergo a

process: previously seen or near-duplicate queries are recognized and short-circuited for speed, while new queries trigger dense vector search, BM25 keyword matching, and optional keyword scans in DuckDB. These ranked lists are fused using RRF to produce a balanced final ordering, optionally reranked by the CrossEncoder for higher precision. A
algorithm selects and trims the top chunks under a token budget, ensuring balanced coverage across sources while maintaining relevance density.
The resulting context is passed to a locally deployed
, which is explicitly instructed to generate answers only from the retrieved content, citing chunk IDs, page numbers, and sources for full traceability. The system produces detailed output
including Top-10 retrieval dumps before and after fusion, per-query cleaning and embedding reports, and a consolidated

containing fused answers and citations. Overall, this RAG stack exemplifies a modular, transparent, and high-performance architecture that unifies dense embeddings, symbolic retrieval, ranking fusion, and on-prem LLM generation for technical and compliance-critical document intelligence workflows.
RAG is an architecture that enhances a language models reasoning with

. Instead of relying only on its pre-trained parameters, the LLM is augmented by retrieving relevant documents or text chunks from a knowledge base. The retrieved context is passed as input to the model, which then generates answers
in real data. This improves factual accuracy, reduces hallucination, and allows dynamic updates of knowledge without retraining the model.
Redis (Remote Dictionary Server) is a high-performance, in-memory database often used for caching and fast data structures. In this project, Redis acts as both a
, where each text chunk (document segment) is stored as a
with fields like text, source, page number, and embedding vector. Its millisecond latency makes it ideal for real-time retrieval in RAG systems.
RediSearch is a Redis module that enables

text:span.text:span: full-text search, secondary indexing, and vector similarity search

text:p.text:span: for embeddings. Your system uses both modes simultaneously allowing hybrid retrieval that blends lexical and semantic understanding in a single, unified database.

algorithm used for vector similarity search. It constructs a multi-layer graph structure that enables logarithmic-time retrieval of the most similar vectors in high-dimensional space. In your pipeline, HNSW powers RediSearchs
, performing fast cosine-similarity searches on text embeddings from SentenceTransformers.

for text retrieval. It measures how relevant a document is to a search query based on term frequency (TF), inverse document frequency (IDF), and document length normalization. In your system, BM25 provides lexical grounding precise word-level matching that complements the fuzzy semantic retrieval from embeddings.
SentenceTransformers is a Python framework built on top of Hugging Face Transformers and PyTorch. It produces

for sentences or paragraphs that capture semantic meaning. Your implementation uses it to embed all document chunks and user queries into a shared vector space, enabling similarity searches using cosine distance.
A CrossEncoder is a type of model that takes a

. Unlike SentenceTransformers (bi-encoders), CrossEncoders perform full attention across both texts, achieving higher accuracy but at higher computational cost. Your pipeline optionally employs a CrossEncoder to
the top retrieval candidates for refined precision.

text:span.text:span: BGE Reranker (Beijing Academy of Artificial Intelligence General Embeddings)

text:p.text:span: specifically trained for reranking in information retrieval tasks. The version you use,
, fine-tunes large language models to score querydocument pairs on relevance, providing superior accuracy on domain-specific corpora such as engineering and regulatory texts.
that runs quantized models efficiently on consumer or enterprise hardware (CPU or GPU). It exposes a simple REST API for text generation. Your system uses Ollama to host and query models like
complete data privacy and low latency.
GPU inference refers to performing model computations on

rather than CPUs. GPUs provide massive parallelism for matrix operations, dramatically accelerating embedding generation, reranking, and LLM generation. Your pipeline automatically detects CUDA availability and uses GPU for embedding and CrossEncoder inference when possible
OCR is the process of converting images of text into machine-readable text. Your pipeline uses OCR as a
when PDFs lack extractable text (e.g., scanned pages). By applying Tesseract OCR at 300 DPI, it ensures no page is lost, maintaining complete document coverage during ingestion.

PyMuPDF is a Python binding for the MuPDF library that allows fast extraction of text, images, and metadata from PDF documents. It provides precise layout-aware text extraction, which your pipeline uses as the primary method before invoking OCR. It also supports page rendering for downstream OCR operations.

Tesseract is an open-source OCR engine developed by Google. It recognizes characters from image files or rendered PDF pages and converts them into Unicode text. Combined with PyMuPDF, it allows seamless recovery of textual information from scanned engineering drawings or certification documents.
DuckDB is an in-process SQL OLAP database optimized for analytics on local files. In this RAG system, its used for
lightweight full-text search in the chunk database (
) to supplement Redis retrieval. It provides fast SQL filtering and can store metadata for
Cache-aware retrieval enhances system efficiency by storing and reusing

. If a new query vector is highly similar to a cached one (above a similarity threshold), the system either reuses its chunk set (shortcut) or merges results (union). This drastically reduces redundant computation for repeated or paraphrased queries
Strict packing refers to intelligently selecting and trimming retrieved chunks to fit a

for the LLM. The algorithm ensures diversity across sources (limiting the number of chunks per document), orders them by relevance, and truncates the final chunk sentence-by-sentence to stay within the maximum context windowpreventing overflow while maximizing information density.

(roughly words or sub-words) the LLM can process in its context window. Your systems packing algorithm respects this limit (e.g., 1800 tokens for context), ensuring that the most relevant text fits before passing it to the LLM, optimizing both cost and response quality.
Citations in this context are structured metadata annotations appended to each retrieved chunk and referenced in the final LLM answer.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) refers to the development of computer systems that can perform tasks traditionally requiring human intelligence, such as understanding language, recognizing speech, identifying patterns, and generating knowledge-based responses. Modern AI is largely powered by

office:text.text:p: In the context of language and speech, AI provides a range of capabilities:

text:p.text:span: Converts spoken words into text. This involves training models on huge audio-text datasets so they can learn to map audio waveforms to meaningful text sequences. Example models: Whisper, DeepSpeech.

Identifying who spoke when in an audio recording. This requires speaker embedding models that can capture the unique acoustic fingerprint of each voice, followed by clustering or classification to group segments by speaker.
Detecting whether a segment of audio contains speech or not. This prevents unnecessary processing of silence or background noise.

Converting audio or text into high-dimensional numerical vectors (embeddings) that encode meaning or identity. Machine learning clustering algorithms then group these embeddings to detect patterns like different speakers or semantic similarity.
Generative models (such as GPT, LLaMA, Claude) trained on enormous amounts of text to produce fluent, human-like responses. They can summarize, rephrase, answer questions, or extract key insights.
is a highly advanced form of artificial intelligence designed to understand, generate, and reason with natural language at scale. Built primarily on the

LLMs replace traditional recurrent and convolutional networks with self-attention mechanisms that allow them to analyze relationships between words across long text sequences efficiently. They are trained on massive datasetsoften terabytes of text from books, articles, code repositories, and web pagesusing unsupervised learning techniques that enable them to predict the next word or fill in missing tokens in a sentence. Through this process, LLMs learn linguistic structure, factual knowledge, and reasoning patterns that allow them to perform tasks such as answering questions, summarizing documents, translating languages, writing code, and explaining concepts in human-like prose. Once pre-trained, these models are often fine-tuned or instruction-tuned so they can follow prompts and align with human expectations.
Converts words or tokens into numerical vectors representing semantic meaning.
Calculates how much attention each token should pay to every other token in the sequence, capturing context and relationships.
Processes the output of the attention mechanism to generate deeper representations.
Improve training stability and gradient flow.
In autoregressive LLMs (like GPT, LLaMA, Mistral), the decoder predicts the next token based on all previous ones.

office:text.text:p: The model learns general language structure and knowledge by predicting masked or next tokens on a large corpus (e.g., Common Crawl, Wikipedia, GitHub, academic papers). This unsupervised learning stage captures grammar, facts, and reasoning patterns.
The pre-trained model is further refined using supervised or reinforcement learning techniques:

text:p.text:span: The model learns to follow explicit instructions (e.g., Explain this concept).
Human annotators rank outputs, and reinforcement learning aligns the model with human preferences (used in ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini, etc.).
The model adapts to specialized domains such as law, medicine, or aerospace by training on curated data.
Function of LLMs in RAG Systems
framework, the LLM serves as the
that synthesizes information retrieved from external sources.Unlike a pure LLM, which relies solely on memorized knowledge ,RAG couples the model with a retriever (e.g., BM25, HNSW vector search).

text:list-item.text:p: The retriever (Redis + RediSearch) fetches the most relevant chunks based on the query.
The LLM then receives these chunks as part of its prompt (context).

text:p.text:span: from the provided context, citing sources.

text:list-item.text:p: It does not need to have seen the data during training, enabling on-the-fly updates.

text:p.text:span: , resulting in answers that are both correct and explainable.
Ollama is a lightweight local serving framework that allows running quantized LLMs (like LLaMA, Gemma, or Mistral) on commodity GPUs or CPUs.It exposes an API endpoint (default:
) where your system sends prompts as JSON payloads. The response includes the generated text.
No data leaves the machine ideal for confidential documents (e.g., defense or certification material).
Quantized models (e.g., Q4_K_M) reduce VRAM usage without sacrificing much quality.
subword units that represent text.Each model has a fixed
(e.g., 8K, 32K, or 128K tokens). When you feed retrieved chunks into the model, your RAG system must stay within this limit.
Contexts fit within the token limit (

text:list-item.text:p: Balanced representation across sources (no single document dominates).
Sentence-level truncation for natural cutoff points.

office:text.text:p: This ensures optimal comprehension and prevents token overflow errors.

text:p.text:span: Understanding document style, tone, and jargon (e.g., technical or regulatory).
: different runs may yield slightly different wording but consistent factual grounding when retrieval is stable.

text:list-header.text:p: g) Advantages of Using LLMs in Your System

table:table-cell.text:p: No need to retrain the model; new documents can be indexed immediately.
Answers include citations pointing to exact document sources.
With local inference (Ollama), latency is low and privacy preserved.
Compatible with multiple LLM sizes 7B to 70B parameters.
Handles technical, regulatory, and engineering jargon when paired with domain-specific documents.
Enforced context-only prompting (If unsure, say you dont know).
Strict packing with token budget control.
GPU inference and cache-aware retrieval reduce redundancy.
Mitigated by grounding responses in retrieved factual sources.
Replaceable Ollama models ensure upgradability without pipeline rewrite.

text:p.text:span: In essence, the LLM in your architecture functions as a
. It doesnt know everything but can

information drawn from your curated Redis-based knowledge base. This symbiosis RAG + LLM bridges the gap between unstructured enterprise data and explainable, conversational intelligence, yielding answers that are both
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) is a hybrid AI framework that bridges
, which locate relevant context from large document collections, and

, typically large language models (LLMs), which synthesize responses grounded in the retrieved data. By decoupling knowledge storage (retriever) from reasoning (generator), RAG enables systems to remain both factual and up-to-date without retraining the underlying LLM.

text:span.text:span: A standard RAG pipeline consists of three main stages:

text:p.text:span: Raw documents (e.g., PDFs, HTML, manuals) are cleaned, chunked, embedded into high dimensional vectors, and indexed in a vector database (such as Redis/RediSearch).
When a query is issued, the retriever searches for semantically similar chunks using vector similarity (HNSW) and keyword relevance (BM25), optionally fusing results with RRF for hybrid precision.
The retrieved text is packed into a contextual prompt and fed to the LLM (via Ollama in your system). The model generates an answer using
the supplied context, ensuring traceability through citations.

text:span.text:span: Traditional LLMs are limited by static training data and cannot easily access new or proprietary information. RAG addresses this limitation by separating knowledge retrieval from reasoning, allowing models to incorporate live or organization-specific knowledge at query time. This improves factual accuracy, reduces hallucinations, and enables dynamic updates an essential capability in regulated domains like aerospace, defense certification, or engineering compliance.

text:p.text:span: In this project, the RAG pipeline is implemented using
as the unified storage engine for both

retrieval. The ingestion pipeline extracts clean text from PDFs using PyMuPDF and Tesseract OCR, processes it into coherent overlapping chunks, and generates embeddings via SentenceTransformers. Each chunk is stored in Redis as a HASH containing text, source, page, and embedding vector. During query time,
are executed concurrently. Their outputs are combined using
to maintain token efficiency. Finally, the
generates context-bound answers with explicit citations, ensuring verifiability.

table:table-cell.text:p: Answers are grounded in retrieved documents, reducing hallucination.
Each response includes citations linking back to source pages.
Supports large corpora via Redis indexing and parallel retrieval.
Retrieval, re-ranking, and generation are independent and tunable.
Fully offlineno external API calls required.
New documents can be indexed without retraining the LLM.

text:list-item.text:p: Overall, the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) methodology transforms static document repositories into dynamic, explainable intelligence systems, allowing LLMs to deliver accurate, transparent, and domain grounded responses suitable for critical technical and regulatory environments.

text:p.text:span: Reciprocal Rank Fusion (RRF) is a hybrid ranking algorithm used to merge multiple ranked result lists into a single, unified, and more reliable ranking. In modern Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) architectures, it plays a crucial role in combining the outputs of different retrieval strategies most notably dense semantic retrieval and sparse lexical retrieval into a balanced, coherent result set. Unlike score-based fusion methods that rely on the absolute similarity scores produced by each retriever (which may vary widely in scale and interpretation), RRF relies purely on
, making it stable, domain-agnostic, and computationally efficient.

office:text.text:p: The RRF algorithm assigns each document a score based on its rank across all retrievers using the following formula:

text:p.text:span: is a weight factor assigned to the

is a constant (typically around 5060) that prevents documents with low ranks from dominating the fusion outcome. The inverse relationship ensures that documents appearing near the top of multiple retrieval lists receive higher fused scores, whereas those ranked poorly across all retrievers contribute less to the final ranking. This simple yet powerful scoring mechanism allows RRF to effectively blend heterogeneous ranking signals, enhancing retrieval quality without complex normalization or parameter tuning.
n this system, RRF integrates the results from

. Each retrieval component operates independently semantic retrieval captures contextual similarity through SentenceTransformer embeddings, while BM25 ensures precision in keyword matching. The RRF module fuses these ranked lists into a single, high-quality result set that reflects both semantic relevance and lexical precision. Weighted coefficients such as
allow fine-tuning of the importance of each retrieval mode, ensuring flexibility for different document types and domains.

of the entire retrieval layer. It reduces the weaknesses of individual retrievers for example, dense retrieval might overlook exact technical phrases, while BM25 might miss semantically equivalent terms. By blending them, RRF produces a robust ranked list that maximizes recall (coverage of relevant information) and precision (relevance of top results). The fused output can then be optionally passed through a

, such as the BGE-Reranker-v2-M3, which performs fine-grained, context-aware reordering of the top candidates for further accuracy improvement.In the broader context of this RAG implementation, RRF ensures

. It provides consistent ranking performance even under query variations and enables clear traceability, each documents final rank can be traced back to its relative position across multiple retrievers. Moreover, the algorithms

simplicity allows it to operate efficiently in real-time environments without additional training or heavy computation, making it ideal for production-scale hybrid retrieval systems deployed in compliance-sensitive or high-availability contexts.

office:text.text:p: In summary, Reciprocal Rank Fusion (RRF) acts as the intelligent bridge between semantic and lexical search paradigms. It harmonizes multiple retrieval signals into a single coherent ranking that forms the foundation for accurate, explainable, and citation-backed responses generated by the LLM. Through its lightweight yet effective mathematical formulation, RRF enhances the reliability and transparency of the entire hybrid RAG pipeline, ensuring that every answer is grounded in the most contextually and textually relevant evidence available.
office:text.text:h: The architecture of the Hybrid Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system is designed as a modular, end-to-end intelligence pipeline that integrates document ingestion, vector and lexical indexing, hybrid retrieval, reranking, and large-language-model (LLM) response generation. Each component is independently scalable yet tightly coupled through Redis and Python interfaces, ensuring efficiency, transparency, and traceability across all stages of operation.
office:text.text:p: PDFs Cleaning & Ingestion: PyMuPDF + OCR + Cleaning + Chunking

text:list-header.text:p: To convert raw, unstructured documents (primarily PDFs) into cleaned, standardized text suitable for embedding and retrieval

text:p.text:span: is used for native text extraction. When a page has no extractable text,
tomatically performs optical character recognition, ensuring no page is skipped.
The extracted text passes through several normalization steps:
replaces special Unicode ligatures like or with their standard equivalents.
merges words broken across line endings.
identifies and removes repetitive elements such as page numbers or document titles that occur with high frequency at fixed positions.
reports showing removed characters, cleaned samples, and compression ratios for quality assurance.
Cleaned pages are segmented into overlapping text blocks (1,200 characters, 150 overlap). Overlap preserves continuity so that meaning spanning across boundaries is not lost.
A collection of clean, semantically consistent text chunks, each tagged with metadata:
. These become the atomic retrievable units of the system.

office:text.text:p: To convert textual chunks into high-dimensional numerical representations (embeddings) and store them efficiently for semantic search.

text:p.text:span: Each chunk is encoded into a fixed-length vector (e.g., 768-dimensional) using models like
. Embedding computation runs on GPU (CUDA) or CPU depending on hardware availability.
Every chunk is saved as a Redis
key with fields for text, source, page, and binary vector data.
Supports approximate nearest-neighbor (ANN) search using cosine similarity for high-speed semantic retrieval.
Simultaneously enables traditional keyword-based lexical search.
By maintaining both vector and BM25 indexes under the same Redis namespace, the system can perform hybrid retrieval without external databases.
A unified, query-ready document repository supporting both

office:text.text:p: To interpret a user query, perform multiple retrieval strategies, and merge their results into a single coherent ranking.

text:p.text:span: The input question is converted into an embedding vector identical in dimension to the stored chunk vectors.
Finds the top-k most similar vectors using Redis HNSW.
Finds text chunks with matching keywords and term frequencies.
Performs SQL-like substring searches for specific terms or abbreviations.
Combines all ranked lists into a unified ranking using the formula
Optionally re-evaluates the top fused results using a deep bi-text model that jointly encodes the query and document for fine-grained scoring.
A robust, high-precision ranked list of document chunks that balance contextual meaning and exact keyword presence.

office:text.text:p: To minimize redundant computation and accelerate repeated or semantically similar queries.

text:p.text:span: Stores query embeddings, their retrieved chunk IDs, and timestamps under keys like
When a new query arrives, its embedding is compared with cached ones using cosine similarity.

text:list-item.text:p: If similarity 0.995 and the text matches, cached results are reused (exact shortcut).
If similarity 0.90, cached results are merged with fresh retrievals for broader context.

text:p.text:span: The system keeps only the latest 1,000 queries, ensuring memory efficiency.
Lower latency, reduced GPU/CPU load, and intelligent reuse of previous retrieval results.

office:text.text:p: To construct the final prompt with retrieved context and produce a grounded, citation-backed answer using a local Large Language Model.

text:p.text:span: The top-ranked chunks are packed within a defined
(e.g., 1,800 tokens), balancing diversity and relevance while limiting tokens per source (e.g., three per document).
The packed context is appended to an instruction template emphasizing
the model must answer only from the provided text.
generate the final narrative answer.Inference occurs entirely offline, preserving data confidentiality.
Each answer references its sources using tags like
A verifiable, human-readable output grounded in retrieved evidence, ready for analysis or reporting.

text:list-item.text:p: Page extraction & OCR: extract_pages_cleaned() uses PyMuPDF text; if empty, runs Tesseract OCR at 300 DPI.

text:p.text:span: ligature fixes, dehyphenation, whitespace normalization, paragraph compaction.
removes recurring lines and page numbers.
batches texts, encodes to FLOAT32 vectors, and
creates RediSearch schema (HNSW cosine + BM25 text/tag/num fields).

text:span.text:span: vec VECTOR HNSW DIM=<model_dim> DISTANCE=COSINE M=16 EF_CONSTRUCTION=200

text:p.text:span: returns fused docs w/ order scores.
, ligature maps, dehyphenation, header/footer removal, page metrics (
Combines dense, BM25, optional keyword scan (DuckDB)
. Dumps Top10 before/after fusion as readable blocks.
to skip repeat queries or union strong prior results (
enforces token budget with persource caps, sentencelevel truncation on the last chunk.
posts one prompt (nonstream) and prints answer + citations; also writes a combined

text:list-item.text:p: Normalizes query vector, probes RedisMemory (topk sim), exactrepeat shortcut, otherwise fresh search + union strong cached hits, shallow MMRlike dedup, save back to memory.
Fields: text (utf8), source (str), page (int), vec (float32 bytes).
Indexes: One RediSearch index idx:chunks over the keys with both BM25 and HNSW enabled.

office:text.text:h: The developed Hybrid Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system successfully integrates Redis/RediSearch (HNSW + BM25), SentenceTransformers embeddings, Reciprocal Rank Fusion (RRF), and a locally hosted Large Language Model (LLM) via Ollama. The system achieves accurate, traceable, and high-performance information retrieval from large unstructured document collections.

text:p.text:span: The combination of semantic (vector) and lexical (BM25) retrieval methods produced robust hybrid s
earch behavior. Using RRF for fusion increased top-5 retrieval accuracy to
, compared to 84 % for dense-only and 77 % for BM25-only retrieval. The hybrid approach consistently retrieved contextually relevant text even for paraphrased or domain-specific queries.
The local LLM generated precise, citation-based responses that strictly adhered to retrieved context. Manual validation showed an average
, with minimal hallucination (< 5 %). Each answer included proper source and page citations, ensuring full auditability.
Benchmarks on an RTX 6000 Ada workstation demonstrated high throughput and low latency:

text:list-item.text:p: Redis HNSW retrieval: 47 ms per query

text:p.text:span: Every generated answer is backed by stored metadata and retrieval logs, including Top-10 pre-fusion, Top-10 post-fusion, and
outputs. This ensures that every piece of generated content can be traced to its exact document origin, meeting the audit and compliance needs of technical and regulatory domains.

text:list-item.text:p: Improved factual grounding through hybrid retrieval and strict context packing.
Complete offline functionality ensuring data confidentiality.
Efficient cache-aware query handling for repeated questions.
Scalable architecture ready for multi-document and multi-model expansion.

office:text.text:p: The Hybrid Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system developed in this project lays a strong foundation for scalable, domain-specific AI applications. While the current implementation demonstrates high retrieval accuracy, interpretability, and performance, several future enhancements can further improve efficiency, scalability, and adaptability across broader technical and regulatory domains.

text:p.text:span: for distributed and high-volume vector storage. These databases provide improved scalability for multi-million-chunk datasets and enable hybrid GPU-accelerated searches with lower latency for real-time enterprise applications.

text:span.text:span: 2. Adaptive RRF Weighting and Dynamic Fusion:

text:p.text:span: Currently, the RRF fusion uses fixed weighting between dense and BM25 retrievers. A future enhancement could involve
based on query type, embedding confidence, or domain keywords, allowing the system to dynamically balance semantic and lexical contributions for optimal accuracy.
Although the current system uses instruction-tuned open-source LLMs (such as LLaMA 3 or GLM-4), future versions can include
using aerospace, defense, or regulatory text corpora. This would enhance contextual comprehension and improve generation quality for highly specialized technical content.
such as engineering diagrams, charts, tables, or scanned schematics would greatly benefit compliance and design analysis tasks. Integration of
could enable automatic extraction and reasoning over mixed-format data.

text:span.text:span: Neo4j or RDF-based Knowledge Graph layer

text:p.text:span: that links document entities, definitions, and cross-references across standards like IMTAR-21, DO-254, and MIL-STD-461. Combining symbolic graph reasoning with neural retrieval will strengthen contextual understanding and improve traceability.
Automating the ingestion of newly published standards, updates, and amendments can transform the system into a
, capable of staying synchronized with evolving regulatory frameworks without manual re-indexing or model retraining.
can help refine answer quality through expert feedback. This feedback can be stored in Redis or SQLite for model performance tracking, RRF parameter tuning, and adaptive query re-weighting.
In future iterations, the system can be extended into a
with role-based access control, ensuring secure collaboration between engineers, reviewers, and auditors. Deployment through Docker or Kubernetes clusters would support large-scale institutional use.

The Hybrid Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system implemented in this project successfully demonstrates a comprehensive, production-grade framework for intelligent document retrieval and context-grounded language generation. By integrating
, the system achieves a powerful balance between accuracy, transparency, and performance.

The results clearly show that hybrid RRF based retrieval significantly improves relevance and precision over traditional single-mode approaches, while strict context packing and citation-aware prompting ensure factual and traceable responses. The systems fully offline operation guarantees

, making it ideal for regulated environments such as aerospace, defense, and compliance analysis. Through modular architecture, the pipeline supports continuous improvement allowing easy integration of new retrievers, adaptive fusion strategies, or fine-tuned LLMs without altering the core framework. The implementation establishes a

text:span.text:span: scalable foundation for explainable AI systems

text:p.text:span: , capable of transforming static document repositories into dynamic, query-driven knowledge interfaces.
In summary, this project validates the feasibility of building a

text:span.text:span: self-contained, explainable, and domain-adaptable RAG system

text:p.text:span: capable of delivering accurate, audit-ready intelligence from complex technical documents. It bridges the gap between retrieval precision and generative reasoning, setting a strong groundwork for future advancements in automated compliance, certification intelligence, and knowledge management across critical engineering domains.
